author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seizes Lysychansk
description: Plus a heat wave engulfs Japan and transgender activists in Pakistan debate protections.
content: Ukraine’s military said Sunday that it had withdrawn from the key eastern city of Lysychansk, the last city in Luhansk Province still held by Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Jasmina Nielsen
title: 3 Dead in Copenhagen Mall Shooting, Police Say
description: The police said that one person was in custody but that it was too early to suggest a motive for the shooting, which happened at the Field’s shopping center on Sunday.
content: Three people were killed and at least three others were critically hurt in a shooting in Copenhagen on Sunday that sent terrified shoppers fleeing for safety in Denmark’s largest shopping center, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Mounting Flight Delays. Stranded Fliers. Airlines Struggle With Surging July 4 Demand.
description: Carriers were dealing with a combination of staff shortages and passenger volume that approached or in some cases exceeded prepandemic levels.
content: Air passengers across the United States faced extensive flight cancellations and delays this weekend, caused by a boom in travel demand coupled with widespread staffing shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Stulberg
title: My O.C.D. Diagnosis Was a Blessing, Until It Became Too Central to My Identity
description: Getting a mental health diagnosis can be a huge relief. But can the label become a problem?
content: Five years ago, seemingly out of nowhere, my brain fell into an abyss of unrelenting intrusive thoughts — What if I harm myself? What if I harm others? What if I’m crazy? — each of which was accompanied by electric shocks of anxiety and full-on sensations of dread. It was, by far, the most terrifying, vexing and isolating period of my life. My first moment of relief came four weeks later, when I finally got in to see a psychiatrist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: The eastern city of Lysychansk is a big prize for Putin.
description: Controlling the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk means Russia could position its forces to mount offensives on cities to the southwest.
content: Russia’s complete control of the Ukrainian city of Lysychansk appears to be a foregone conclusion: Soviet flags are flying in the center and Ukrainian troops have withdrawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes and George Etheredge
title: Buffalo’s ‘Other Story’ Is Told in Redevelopment and Growth
description: A decade-long effort to transform industrial relics is showing signs of progress and expanding the city’s population for the first time in 70 years.
content: BUFFALO — Buffalo was riding a decade-long economic turnaround when a racially motivated attack by a gunman killed 10 people in May, overshadowing the progress. While the city grieved, it also had to reckon with unflattering portrayals of the East Side, the impoverished neighborhood where the massacre took place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Once a Crucial Refuge, ‘Gayborhoods’ Lose L.G.B.T.Q. Residents in Major Cities
description: Many are choosing to live elsewhere in search of cheaper housing and better amenities. They are finding growing acceptance in other communities after decades of political and social changes.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Cleve Jones has lived in the Castro neighborhood for nearly 50 years, almost from the day he graduated from high school in Phoenix and hitchhiked to California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire
title: An American’s Murky Path From Russian Propagandist to Jan. 6
description: Charles Bausman, a former financial executive who runs websites that promote far-right views, recorded footage in the Capitol for a Russian television producer. Soon after, he fled to Moscow as a “political refugee.”
content: In security footage from Jan. 6, it is easy to overlook the thin man wearing a red Trump hat who filters into the U.S. Capitol Building to record the mayhem with his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Kamila Hrabchuk and Vivian Yee
title: As City Falls, Ukraine’s Last Hope in Luhansk Falls With It
description: Lysychansk managed to hold out for a week after its twin city, Sievierodonetsk, was captured. But on Sunday a pro-Russian flag flew there, as well.
content: The last major city held by Ukraine in the heavily contested eastern province of Luhansk has fallen, military officials on both sides said Sunday, giving Moscow a milestone victory in its campaign to capture the Donbas, the mineral-rich region bordering Russia that has long been in President Vladimir V. Putin’s sights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James R. Oestreich
title: Music’s Towering Intellectual, With an Appetite for Trouble
description: Richard Taruskin, who died on Friday, is remembered by his former editor at The New York Times and elsewhere.
content: His keeper, not his editor, I used to call myself in affectionate jest — and with enormous pride and respect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Amid Ukraine War, Orchestras Rethink ‘1812 Overture,’ a July 4 Rite
description: Some ensembles have decided not to perform Tchaikovsky’s overture, written as commemoration of Russia’s defeat of Napoleon’s army.
content: With its earsplitting rounds of cannon fire and triumphal spirit, Tchaikovsky’s “1812 Overture” has been a staple of Fourth of July festivities across the United States for decades, serving as a rousing prelude to glittering displays of fireworks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Australia’s new prime minister promises increased aid during visit to Ukraine.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the visit as the first by an Australian prime minister to his country during their history of diplomatic relations.
content: The new prime minister of Australia, Anthony Albanese, promised more military aid and more sanctions against Russia during a visit to Ukraine on Sunday that signaled continued resolve by liberal democracies to support Ukraine’s effort to rebut the Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Argentina’s Economy Minister Abruptly Quits, Exposing Rifts in Government
description: Martin Guzmán had negotiated a deal to restructure $44 billion of the country’s debt. His departure threatens to destabilize an already shaken economy.
content: BUENOS AIRES (Reuters) — Argentina’s economy minister abruptly resigned on Saturday night, a move that threatens to further destabilize an economy already shaken by sky-high inflation, rising energy costs and growing fears over possible new defaults on debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: The Week in Business: Spending More, Getting Less
description: The stock market had its worst first six months of a year since 1970. The Supreme Court dealt a blow to Biden’s climate plans. And the June jobs report is coming.
content: Consumers kept spending in May, but they got less for their money. Adjusted for inflation, spending fell in May for the first time this year — by 0.4 percent, as spending rose less than prices. Spending was also weaker in the first four months of 2022 than previously believed. Though Americans have hardly stopped making purchases even as prices for gas, groceries, travel and just about everything else rise, there are signs that high prices may be starting to take a toll on demand. Big-ticket items, in particular, have been affected, starting with the housing market, which has cooled off in recent weeks as high prices have combined with rising mortgage rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Women who were raped by Russian soldiers yearn for justice.
description: Rapes were among the many atrocities Russian troops inflicted on Ukrainian civilians during weeks of occupation in the Kyiv suburbs and elsewhere. But the challenges of prosecuting the assaults are daunting.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Every day, Viktoriya has to walk past the house where she was raped by a Russian soldier the same age as her teenage son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Austin Ramzy
title: Four killed after explosions in a Russian city near the Ukraine border.
description: The Russians said its air-defense systems shot down three missiles, but one fell to the ground in central Belgorod.
content: Explosions hit the center of a Russian city just north of Ukraine early Sunday, killing four, officials said, in the deadliest known episode affecting civilians in Russia since the start of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christensen
title: Pay Attention to These Old Women. You’ll Learn Something.
description: Alice Elliott Dark’s ambitious new novel, “Fellowship Point,” explores a lifetime of lessons about friendship, loyalty and land.
content: Novels featuring older characters are well suited to an exploration of questions about time, history and change. Unlike younger protagonists, they already know who they’ve become and what they’ve made of their lives. They’re not finished yet, but they are as busy reckoning with the past as they are living in the present. They are in full possession of the bulk of their life’s trajectory, so their primary aim is to resolve and make sense of things before they die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: A Season on the Line
description: The Chicago White Sox have been slowed by injuries and mocked for odd decisions. A 19-game stretch against division rivals could make or break their year.
content: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Andrew Vaughn, the Chicago White Sox outfielder, grew up in Santa Rosa, the Northern California town best known for its wineries and as the home of the cartoonist Charles M. Schulz. Vaughn said his father knew Schulz, the creator of the “Peanuts” comic strip, a little and spent a lot of time at Snoopy’s Home Ice, an ice rink in town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: The Culture War That More Christians Should Be Fighting
description: If we don’t talk about economic justice, we are advancing an emaciated view of Christian political engagement.
content: Let’s talk about the culture war we should be fighting. When we think of what’s important to the “religious right” or to “white evangelicals,” the focus tends to be on social issues: abortion, the role of religion in public life, conflicts around sexual orientation and gender identity, and lately, controversy over critical race theory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In Northern Ireland, Old Passions Are Smoldering Anew
description: Brexit and so-called legacy legislation are reviving sensitive issues of Catholic and Protestant identity that civic leaders have sought to dampen.
content: DERRY, Northern Ireland — Few cities are as caught between hope and history as Derry, the birthplace of the modern Troubles but also the backdrop for “Derry Girls,” the exuberant, wildly popular British TV series that chronicles the lives of five teenagers as that bloody period was drawing to an end in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Summer’s Soft Return
description: The heat rises at parties for The Drift, New Wave New York and the Swedish consulate’s Midsummer Festival.
content: Summer is here, officially. There are signs: There’s the solstice of course, and the L.G.B.T. Pride March. But there are more subtle markers around the city: conviviality on fire escapes; weekends that are thinner with locals and thicker with tourists; and no one wears a thing. This last ritual was challenged on June 23 as writers, agents and editors ambled uptown to celebrate the second anniversary of the literary magazine The Drift, hosted at the David Zwirner gallery on East 69th Street. Guests in demure dress listened to speeches from The Drift’s editors, the novelist Joshua Cohen and a beshorted Hilton Als, who curated the gallery’s current show of Frank Walker’s work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Nick Kyrgios, a Dream and a Nightmare for Wimbledon, Is Winning
description: The Australian’s matches and news conferences have become irresistible theater — some call them a circus — a blessing and a curse for a sport that is always battling for attention.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — All white is the dress code at Wimbledon, the oldest and most traditional of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments. So when Nick Kyrgios wears a black hat for his on-court interview, he is sending a message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: In Ukraine, U.S. Veterans Step In Where the Military Will Not
description: Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia, despite warnings from the Pentagon.
content: A democracy came under attack. The United States saw a threat to an ally and also to the entire world order, but it feared that sending troops could spark a nuclear war. So, instead, it supplied weapons. And a small number of American Special Operations trainers started quietly working with the local military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Investigators of War Crimes in Ukraine Face Formidable Challenges
description: International agencies are joining Ukrainian prosecutors in what may be the biggest effort ever to hold war criminals to account. But the difficulties and dangers they face are exceptional, too.
content: KOROPY, Ukraine — Four men tugged at long strips of fabric to lift a coffin out of the gaping hole in the backyard of a small house. They flung the lid open to reveal the moldy corpse of Oleksiy Ketler, who had been killed instantly by shrapnel when a mortar fell on the road in Koropy, a village outside Kharkiv in northeastern Ukraine, in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: 3-D Printing Grows Beyond Its Novelty Roots
description: With the technology improving and costs falling, 3-D printing could be poised to play a major role in manufacturing.
content: DEVENS, Mass. — The machines stand 20 feet high, weigh 60,000 pounds and represent the technological frontier of 3-D printing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: James Bardeen, an Expert on Unraveling Einstein’s Equations, Dies at 83
description: A scion of a renowned family of physicists, he helped set the stage for what has been called the golden age of black hole astrophysics.
content: James Bardeen, who helped elucidate the properties and behavior of black holes, setting the stage for what has been called the golden age of black hole astrophysics, died on June 20 in Seattle. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Troy Closson and Julie Tate
title: 76 Fake Charities Shared a Mailbox. The I.R.S. Approved Them All.
description: The tax agency is the gatekeeper for America’s charity system, but reduced vetting has opened the door to scams.
content: The “American Cancer Society of Michigan,” state authorities say, was a fake charity. And not even a good fake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Jannik Sinner Beats Carlos Alcaraz in a Match Befitting the Stage
description: The young talents made their Centre Court debuts hours after Wimbledon celebrated the main stage’s 100th anniversary, and they provided a foil to a contentious match the day before.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — It was a long weekend full of contrasts at the All England Club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: The Race to the Start Line: Returning to Running After Having Covid-19
description: It’s not easy to tell runners to slow down when many of their goals are to speed up.
content: In March 2020, Dr. Niall Elliott was planning for the summer Olympics with his colleagues at the British Olympic Association. Plans were drawn for what to do if an athlete suffered a catastrophic injury or a mental health crisis in the final lead up to the Games. There were meetings on how to move some of the world’s finest athletes across the globe and how to address logistical snafus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: How a Military Base in Illinois Helps Keep Weapons Flowing to Ukraine
description: Thousands of logisticians are responsible for making sure that U.S. military aid reaches its destination, on planes, trains and ships.
content: SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill. — In a room dimly lit by television screens, dozens of airmen tapped away at computers and worked the phones. Some were keeping watch over a high-priority mission to move a Russian-made Mi-17 helicopter from a base in Arizona to a destination near Ukraine’s border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Abortion Laws Around the World
description: The U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling on abortion quickly led to bans in at least seven states, a shift toward criminalization that runs counter to recent easings in countries that had longstanding bans.
content: The Supreme Court’s elimination of the constitutional right to abortion, after nearly a half-century, has made the United States one of the few countries actively strengthening abortion restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Florida Man Posing as Disney Worker Charged in Removal of R2-D2 at Hotel
description: David Proudfoot told investigators he had applied for a security job at Walt Disney World and hoped to prove himself by highlighting lapses in Disney’s oversight.
content: A Florida man who said he applied for a security job at Walt Disney World in Florida wanted to impress his would-be bosses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shruti Swamy
title: A Mermaid Makes for a Strange Kind of Immigrant
description: Equal parts fairy tale, ghost story and history, Monique Roffey’s new novel explores the legacy of colonialism and enslavement on a Caribbean island.
content: Off the shores of Black Conch, an imagined island in the Caribbean, in 1976, two American white men and a crew of Black island sailors hook a mermaid and wrestle her out of the water. Almost all the sailors experience a deep unease, “a sense of blasphemy,” at the act of capture: “So close, she was terrifying, a person there, no doubt about it; a trapped and dying woman.” The mermaid, Aycayia — huge, wounded, furious, utterly vulnerable, “crawling with sea-lice” — brings out powerful impulses in the men: to harm, to possess, to touch, to mark her, despite or even because of the hatred in her “tinfoil eyes.” This violent, mesmerizing scene begins “The Mermaid of Black Conch,” signaling the book’s ambition. Monique Roffey’s sixth novel is a fairy tale: The mermaid casts off her tail, regains her legs, falls in love, battles an ancient curse. But it is a ghost story too, the people and the very land of Black Conch haunted by the island’s legacy of colonialism and enslavement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: The Persistent Myth That Restricting Abortion Rights Won’t Affect the Rich
description: The notion that rich women will be fine, regardless of what the law says, is probably comforting to some. But it is simply not true.
content: If there’s one assumption about abortion rights that’s accepted across the ideological spectrum, it’s this: The Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade will mostly affect the poor; rich women will still be able to access abortions when they need them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Nightingale
title: Peter Brook, Celebrated Stage Director of Scale and Humanity, Dies at 97
description: He was called “the greatest innovator of his generation,” leaving an indelible mark with plays, musicals, opera and a relentless curiosity.
content: Peter Brook, whose ambitious, adventurous and endlessly creative stage work ranged across seven decades on both sides of the Atlantic and earned him a place among the greatest theater directors of the 20th century, died on Saturday. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Hunter Reynolds, Artist Who Dressed Up AIDS, Dies at 62
description: After he learned he was H.I.V. positive, he began making art — often performing as his gown-wearing alter ego — that told stories about the condition.
content: One night in 1989, Hunter Reynolds, then a 30-year-old artist living in New York City, made himself up at home with the help of a friendly drag queen. He was intrigued with the results: his handsome face embellished and transformed, neither man nor woman, like an androgynous cabaret star in Berlin during the Weimar years. He tossed on a tweed coat and headed out to various art-world events. Friends didn’t recognize him, so he pretended to be a performance artist visiting from Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Stein with text by Amitava Kumar
title: An Ode to the Queen City of the Hudson
description: When the snow gives way to the dog days of summer, many locals find some relief at the swimming hole on Wappinger Creek.
content: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — When I accepted a job to teach literature and writing at Vassar College in the summer of 2005, a colleague told me that Poughkeepsie — lesser known to some as the Queen City of the Hudson — was a city caught in post-industrial decline. I had a vague notion of what that looked like: boarded up homes and offices, the husk of dead factories with broken windows and overgrown grass, rusted cars, businesses gone to seed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Dept. Braces for Summer of Violent Crime
description: Top officials at the department met with prosecutors and the local police in Philadelphia in an effort to help cities prepare for a hot-weather crime wave marked by the Fourth of July.
content: PHILADELPHIA — The motorcade carrying Lisa O. Monaco, the No. 2 law enforcement official in the United States, maneuvered between potholes, and people, on Kensington Avenue when her driver braked for a man wandering into traffic with a hypodermic needle dangling from his arm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Demand Is Robust.’ Fireworks Come Roaring Back This Summer.
description: Pyrotechnic companies say they’re staging July Fourth shows at prepandemic levels, even as some cities cancel celebrations because of supply-chain and drought concerns.
content: During the early months of the pandemic, the Grucci fireworks business, which has operated from the United States for more than a century, saw the demand for its Independence Day shows plummet at a rate the family hadn’t seen since the Great Depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Abortion, Like Prohibition, Has a Clear Racial Dimension
description: How long before this unpopular repression also loses favor and falls into decline?
content: Last week, David Frum wrote a fascinating article for The Atlantic comparing our current abortion battle to Prohibition, another contentious issue that bitterly divided the nation. After a long, “titanic” struggle, the temperance movement succeeded in imposing a nationwide ban on alcohol — only to have it decline and collapse 13 years later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Big Ben’s Bongs Will Soon Ring Out Again Across London
description: Next to the Houses of Parliament, the tower that houses the enormous bell has been undergoing renovation since 2017.
content: LONDON — For five years, the most famous clock tower in Britain was hidden behind an ugly fortress of scaffolding, and its hourly bong was rendered mute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel McGraw and Luke Vander Ploeg
title: Videos of Jayland Walker Shooting by Police Raise More Questions
description: Mr. Walker’s family urged calm as protests continued in Akron, Ohio.
content: AKRON, Ohio — A 25-year-old Black man who was killed last week by police officers in Akron, Ohio, suffered more than 60 gunshot wounds but was unarmed at the time, the police chief said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Man Dies After Truck Propelled by Jet Engines Crashes at Michigan Air Show
description: The vehicle, called a Shockwave Jet Truck, was racing two planes when it crashed, killing the driver, officials said.
content: The driver of a truck that could top 350 miles per hour because it was powered by jet engines died after the vehicle crashed on Saturday while racing two airplanes at an air show in Michigan, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: In Pam Tanowitz’s ‘Song of Songs’ the Beloved Is Beauty
description: Her new dance at Bard, a collaboration with the composer David Lang, is a refined, restrained and sometimes breathtaking response to the biblical poem.
content: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — “Kiss me.” No sooner has the biblical Song of Songs begun than the speaker is making a move. For scripture, the poem is pretty salacious, which is one reason it has inspired many interpretations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: When It Comes Down to It
description: Celebrate the holiday with Bruce Haight’s patriotic puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Independence Day, solvers! Today we have a puzzle from Bruce Haight, who is making his 59th appearance in the New York Times Crossword. Mr. Haight has constructed a timely and thematically appropriate puzzle to celebrate the Fourth of July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: At the Met, Protest and Poetry About Water
description: As climate change and government actions lead to water scarcity and desecration, Native American artists send an urgent message.
content: In a transfixing two-minute video called “River (The Water Serpent)” in the Metropolitan Museum’s American Wing we see a drone shot of a snow-flecked landscape where a crowd has gathered. Each of its members holds a vertical mirrored panel. Together, on cue, they place the panels horizontally over their heads, reflective side skyward, and begin a procession. At first, it’s loose and tidally pooling and eddying. Then it tightens into a stream of light, gains velocity, and spirals like a whirlpool.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 3, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 3, 2022.
content: An article last Sunday about George Michael misstated the location of his childhood home. It was in Edgware, not East Finchley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: New Insights Into Trump’s State of Mind on Jan. 6 Chip Away at Doubts
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has weathered scandals by keeping his intentions under wraps, but recent testimony paints a stark portrait of a man willing to do almost anything to hang onto power.
content: WASHINGTON — He was not speaking metaphorically. It was not an offhand comment. President Donald J. Trump had every intention of joining a mob of supporters he knew to be armed and dangerous as it marched to the Capitol. And there had even been talk of marching into the House chamber himself to disrupt Congress from ratifying his election defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Listeria Outbreak Is Linked to Ice Cream, C.D.C. Says
description: Big Olaf Ice Cream products, which are made in Florida, have sickened people across 10 states, the federal authorities said.
content: A listeria outbreak blamed for the death of one person and the hospitalization of 22 people across 10 states has been linked to ice cream made in Florida, the federal authorities said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Dom Juan’ Review: The Perks of Being a Professional Hypocrite
description: Piety is just a pose in Ashley Tata’s gender-swapped production of Molière’s tragicomedy at Bard’s SummerScape festival.
content: It’s a funny feeling and not always a welcome one when a play reaches out across the centuries and punches you in the throat. This happens toward the end of “Dom Juan,” Ashley Tata’s gender-swapped production of Molière’s 1665 tragicomedy at Bard’s SummerScape festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: A Clunky Mask May Be the Answer to Airborne Disease and N95 Waste
description: Experts say the U.S. government has unintentionally encouraged a dependency on imported masks by failing to promote elastomeric respirators, a reusable mask that is domestically produced.
content: In the early 1990s, long before P.P.E., N95 and asymptomatic transmission became household terms, federal health officials issued guidelines for how medical workers should protect themselves from tuberculosis during a resurgence of the highly infectious respiratory disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: New Dementia Prevention Method May Be Behavioral, Not Prescribed
description: As experimental drugs prove ineffective against increasing dementia cases in the U.S., researchers argue that improving eyesight can have an effect.
content: Dementia cases are climbing along with an aging world population, and yet another much-anticipated Alzheimer’s medication, crenezumab, has proved ineffective in clinical trials — the latest of many disappointments. Public health experts and researchers argue that it is past time to turn our attention to a different approach — focusing on eliminating a dozen or so already known risk factors, like untreated high blood pressure, hearing loss and smoking, rather than on an exorbitantly priced, whiz-bang new drug.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘She Wanted to Celebrate by Eating at Her Favorite Hot Pot Restaurant’
description: A long walk to Queens, a sidewalk singalong and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Suing New York, Over and Over, for Transgender Rights
description: Mariah Lopez first sued the city at age 13. Her latest settlement has forced the city to overhaul how it treats transgender people who are homeless.
content: Mariah Lopez has been suing New York City for transgender rights since she was a child.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Gayborhoods’ Falling Victim to Rents and Social Change
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 3, 2022.
content: “Gayborhoods are going away. People need to pay attention to this. When people are dispersed, when they no longer live in geographic concentrations, when they no longer inhabit specific precincts, we lose a lot. We lose political power.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Behind the Scenes of the Supreme Court
description: Getting a sense of the mood after a momentous term.
content: A few weeks ago, I asked Adam Liptak — The Times’s Supreme Court correspondent — to preview the major cases that would make up the end of the court’s term. Adam was prophetic, correctly forecasting every big ruling. Today, he returns to the newsletter, answering my questions about the behind-the-scenes atmosphere at the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: ‘The Pro-Life Generation’: Young Women Fight Against Abortion Rights
description: Many American women mourned the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe, but for others it is a moment of triumph and a matter of human rights.
content: DALLAS — The rollback of abortion rights has been received by many American women with a sense of shock and fear, and warnings about an ominous decline in women’s status as full citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: The Far Right and Far Left Agree on One Thing: Women Don’t Count
description: Tolerance for one group doesn’t need to mean intolerance for another.
content: Perhaps it makes sense that women — those supposedly compliant and agreeable, self-sacrificing and everything-nice creatures — were the ones to finally bring our polarized country together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Prosecutors Defend Decision to Place R. Kelly on Suicide Watch
description: The singer, who was given a 30-year sentence last week for sex trafficking and racketeering, is challenging the decision by jail authorities.
content: Federal prosecutors on Saturday defended the decision to place the R&B artist R. Kelly on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, where he has remained since being sentenced to 30 years in federal prison for sex trafficking and racketeering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Light
title: Father Figure: The Tortured Life of George Michael
description: James Gavin’s engrossing biography of the singer takes the measure of a gifted, tragic and infuriating man.
content: In 1993, Princess Diana asked her friend George Michael to help organize a benefit concert for World AIDS Day. He came through magnificently, lining up the other acts and delivering a strong and heartfelt headlining set of his own. Then when it came time for the show to air as a TV special, the English singer insisted on seeing the footage, altering the sequence of performers and recutting the shots of himself onstage because he thought his butt looked big. According to a former BBC producer, “‘Never work with children, animals or George Michael’ became an industry mantra after that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: At Least Six Die in Glacier Collapse in Italy’s Dolomites
description: The glacier has been shrinking for years, and recent high temperatures may have contributed to the collapse, a rescue service official said.
content: At least six people died and eight were injured after a chunk of a glacier collapsed in Italy’s Alps on Sunday, said Walter Milan, a spokesman for Italy’s National Alpine and Speleological Rescue Corps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Just before a holiday full of family and friends, take a moment to cook for yourself.
content: Good morning. What a gift a Sunday meal before a national holiday is, if you’re lucky enough not to be working. Monday’s for cookouts and family, for fireworks real and metaphorical. Sunday’s for you.
source.name: The New York Times

title: America the Imperfect, on the Fourth of July
description: Reflections on America, in response to a column by Pamela Paul. Also: School safety; Microsoft and unions; abortion pills; God and miscarriages.
content: To the Editor:
